summary: This document provides a comprehensive overview of Jeffrey Epstein's life, including his career as a financier, his criminal proceedings, and various allegations of sexual abuse. It details his relationships with notable figures, his financial ventures, and the legal ramifications of his actions, including his 2008 conviction for soliciting prostitution from an underage girl. This document discusses allegations against Jeffrey Epstein, particularly focusing on Virginia Roberts' claims of being held as a sex slave by Epstein and others, including Prince Andrew and Alan Dershowitz. It mentions various lawsuits and investigations related to Epstein, including a potential cover-up by the FBI and the involvement of high-profile individuals like Donald Trump and Bill Clinton. This article discusses the rise and fall of Jeffrey Epstein, detailing his transition from a math teacher to a Wall Street investment banker and his subsequent legal troubles related to sex offenses. It highlights his connections with powerful figures, his wealth, and the allegations against him, including running a sexual abuse ring.

persons.name: Jeffrey Edward Epstein
persons.context: Epstein is the central figure in the document, detailing his career, wealth, and criminal activities.

persons.name: Alan C. Greenberg
persons.context: Greenberg is mentioned as a notable figure in Epstein's early career, having been one of his students at the Dalton School.

persons.name: Leslie Wexner
persons.role: Founder and chairman of The Limited
persons.context: Wexner is noted as a significant client of Epstein's financial firm and is mentioned in relation to Epstein's wealth.

persons.name: Donny Deutsch
persons.context: Deutsch is mentioned as one of the bidders for New York magazine alongside Epstein.

persons.name: Nelson Peitz
persons.context: Peitz is mentioned as a competitor in the bidding for New York magazine.

persons.name: Mortimer Zuckerman
persons.context: Zuckerman is noted for his partnership with Epstein in financing Radar magazine.

persons.name: Harvey Weinstein
persons.context: Weinstein is mentioned as another bidder for New York magazine.

persons.name: Bruce Wasserstein
persons.context: Wasserstein is noted for ultimately winning the bid for New York magazine.

persons.name: Bill Clinton
persons.role: Former President of the United States
persons.context: Clinton is mentioned as one of Epstein's associates, highlighting the powerful contacts Epstein maintained.

persons.name: Kevin Spacey
persons.context: Spacey is mentioned as one of Epstein's associates, further illustrating Epstein's connections.

persons.name: Chris Tucker
persons.context: Tucker is mentioned as another individual who traveled with Epstein.

persons.name: Prince Andrew
persons.context: Prince Andrew's friendship with Epstein is mentioned, along with his denial of allegations related to Epstein's activities.

persons.name: Alfredo Rodriguez
persons.context: Rodriguez is mentioned in relation to his obstruction charge for failing to turn over evidence related to Epstein.

persons.name: Gerald Lefcourt
persons.context: Lefcourt is mentioned as part of Epstein's defense team during his legal proceedings.

persons.name: Alan Dershowitz
persons.context: Dershowitz is noted as part of Epstein's defense team and is later implicated in allegations of sexual abuse.

persons.name: Ken Starr
persons.context: Starr is mentioned as a member of Epstein's defense team.

persons.name: Virginia Roberts
persons.context: Alleged in a sworn affidavit that she was held as a sex slave by Epstein and named several high-profile individuals involved in her abuse.

persons.name: Lisa Bloom
persons.context: Bloom is mentioned as a legal analyst discussing the credibility of claims against Epstein.

persons.name: Donald Trump
persons.context: Mentioned as having been called as a witness in a case against Epstein and having a long-standing friendship with him.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Epstein is described as a Wall Street investment banker turned disgraced sex offender, known for his powerful connections and wealth.

persons.name: Naomi Campbell
persons.context: Campbell is noted as one of Epstein's associates, part of his extensive network.

persons.name: Les Wexner
persons.context: Wexner is identified as a billionaire who was a client of Epstein, though he has since cut ties.

persons.name: Sarah Ferguson
persons.context: Ferguson is mentioned in relation to her past financial dealings with Epstein, which she later regretted.

connections.description: Epstein taught calculus and physics at the Dalton School, where Greenberg was a student.
Wexner was a significant client of Epstein's financial management firm.
Epstein and Zuckerman were equal partners in financing Radar magazine.
Prince Andrew is noted as a longtime friend of Epstein, with implications of deeper connections.
Roberts is one of the alleged victims of Epstein's sexual abuse.
Dershowitz was part of Epstein's defense team during his legal proceedings.
Virginia Roberts alleges that Jeffrey Epstein held her as a sex slave from 1999 to 2002.
Virginia Roberts claims that Prince Andrew was one of the individuals who abused her while she was under Epstein's control.
Virginia Roberts has made allegations against Alan Dershowitz, which he denies and is taking legal action over.
Donald Trump has known Jeffrey Epstein for many years and has described him as a 'terrific guy.'
Epstein and Clinton are noted to have been associates, part of Epstein's powerful network.
Spacey is listed among Epstein's associates, suggesting a social connection.
Campbell is mentioned as part of Epstein's extensive network of associates.
Wexner was a client of Epstein, indicating a professional relationship.
Prince Andrew's friendship with Epstein is highlighted, with Andrew denying any wrongdoing.
Ferguson is identified as Andrew's former wife, with a past financial connection to Epstein.

events.title: Epstein's Guilty Plea
events.description: Epstein pleaded guilty to a single state charge of soliciting prostitution from underage girls and was sentenced to 18 months in prison.

events.title: Initial Allegations
events.description: A woman contacted police alleging her 14-year-old stepdaughter was taken to Epstein's mansion and paid for sexual acts.

events.title: Probable Cause Affidavit
events.description: Palm Beach police filed a probable cause affidavit recommending multiple charges against Epstein.

events.title: Grand Jury Proceedings
events.description: A grand jury returned a single charge of felony solicitation of prostitution against Epstein.

events.title: Judge's Ruling on Prince Andrew
events.description: Judge Kenneth Marra ruled that allegations against Prince Andrew had no bearing on a lawsuit seeking to reopen Epstein's plea agreement.

events.title: Virginia Roberts' Allegations
events.description: Virginia Roberts alleges in a sworn affidavit that she was held as a sex slave by Epstein and named several high-profile individuals involved.

events.title: Trump Called as Witness
events.description: Reports indicate that President Donald Trump was called as a witness in a new case against Epstein.

events.title: Epstein Arrest
events.description: Epstein was arrested after allegations surfaced regarding his solicitation of a minor for sex.

events.title: FBI Investigation
events.description: An FBI investigation was launched after Epstein's arrest, identifying multiple potential victims.

events.title: Plea Deal
events.description: Epstein negotiated a plea deal, pleading guilty to a minor charge and serving a short sentence.

events.title: Ongoing Lawsuit
events.description: A lawsuit against the US government by Epstein's alleged victims continues, seeking to challenge the plea deal.

locations: Little Saint James, U.S. Virgin Islands
keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein was convicted in 2008 for soliciting an underage girl for prostitution and served 13 months in prison.
Epstein's financial career included working at Bear Stearns and founding his own firm, J. Epstein & Co.
He had notable clients including Leslie Wexner and was involved in various high-profile financial dealings.
Epstein was accused of running a sexual abuse ring and lending underage girls to powerful individuals.
Multiple lawsuits have been filed against Epstein, with many settled out of court, and some allegations remain open.
Virginia Roberts alleged she was held as a sex slave by Epstein from 1999 to 2002.
Roberts named Prince Andrew and Alan Dershowitz as individuals who abused her.
Donald Trump was reportedly called as a witness in a case against Epstein.
Dershowitz is taking legal action over the allegations made by Roberts.
Claims made by Roberts had not been tested in any law court as of 2016.
Epstein was raised in a tough Brooklyn neighborhood and began his career as a math teacher.
He transitioned to Wall Street after being introduced to a partner at Bear Stearns.
Epstein's wealth and influence allowed him to build connections with powerful figures across various sectors.
He was arrested in 2005 following allegations of soliciting a minor for sex, leading to an FBI investigation.
Epstein negotiated a controversial plea deal in 2008, which has been challenged by his alleged victims in ongoing lawsuits.
